crossref.abstract: <jats:title>Summary</jats:title><jats:p>Static (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SS</jats:styled-content>) and dynamic stretching (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DS</jats:styled-content>) can lead to subsequent performance impairments or enhancement with the stretched limb. Crossover or non‐local muscle fatigue (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">NLMF</jats:styled-content>) refers to unilateral fatigue‐induced impairments in a contralateral or non‐exercised muscle. Whereas there are conflicting findings in the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">NLMF</jats:styled-content> literature, there are few studies examining the effect of an acute bout of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SS</jats:styled-content> or <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DS</jats:styled-content> on contralateral flexibility, torque or power. Fourteen highly trained subjects (means ± standard deviations: 18 ± 2 years; 179·4 ± 4·6 cm; 70·5 ± 6·3 kg; %body fat: 10·7 ± 2·5%) were tested before and following separate sessions of eight repetitions of 30 s of unilateral hip flexion <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SS</jats:styled-content> or <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DS</jats:styled-content>. Pre‐ and postintervention testing at 1 and 10 min included hip flexor range of motion (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">ROM</jats:styled-content>), isokinetic leg flexion torque and power at 60°.s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> and 300°.s<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> of the stretched and contralateral limbs. The stretched limb had a 6·3% (<jats:italic>P </jats:italic>= 0·01; <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">ES</jats:styled-content>: 0·91) <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">ROM</jats:styled-content> increase with <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DS</jats:styled-content> at 10 min. The contralateral non‐stretched hip flexors experienced <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">ROM</jats:styled-content> increases with <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SS</jats:styled-content> of 5·7% (<jats:italic>P </jats:italic>= 0·02; <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">ES</jats:styled-content>: 0·68) from pretest to 1 min post‐test, whereas <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DS</jats:styled-content> showed 7·1% (<jats:italic>P<</jats:italic>0·0001; <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">ES</jats:styled-content>: 1·09) and 8·4% (<jats:italic>P </jats:italic>= 0·005; <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">ES</jats:styled-content>: 0·89) increases, respectively. There were no relative differences in <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">ROM</jats:styled-content> changes between conditions or limbs nor any stretch‐induced changes in isokinetic torque or power. In conclusion, unilateral <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SS</jats:styled-content> and <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DS</jats:styled-content> augment contralateral limb <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">ROM</jats:styled-content> likely through an increased stretch tolerance.</jats:p>
title: Unilateral static and dynamic hamstrings stretching increases contralateral hip flexion range of motion
